item.title: No, NetEase Isn't Ditching Generative AI
item.content:encoded:
Chinese gaming giant NetEase has issued a statement flatly denying that it's abandoning generative AI use during game development and telling its studios not to use the technology anymore.

In an interview with Eurogamer yesterday, industry veteran Suda51 claimed that not using AI "started as a NetEase policy for all their companies", and that NetEase "folded" its AI research division before telling their studios "not to use AI in games, to not use it at all".

However, in a statement given to FRVR earlier today, NetEase refuted this claim, flatly saying that it "isn't true" and that the company "even [has] a GDC talk about AI" coming as part of the developer conference later this year.

As FRVR points out, Where Winds Meet, an MMO released in November and published by NetEase, has generative AI woven into its DNA; it's in everything from NPC conversations to face generation and more.

Niko Partners research director Daniel Ahmad also confirmed that NetEase is still in favor of generative AI, citing a statement in which the company declares that the situation Suda51 describes "did not occur" and that NetEase has "not published any related policies".

Generative AI remains a hot topic when it comes to game development. Almost 20% of the top new sellers on Steam used gen AI last year, and more than 500 demos in October's Steam Next Fest promo disclosed usage of generative AI as well.

Studios like Krafton, Netflix, and EA have declared in favor of generative AI, but it's not being embraced by everyone; BioShock and Judas creator Ken Levine has said he's "not overly impressed" by the technology, while Manor Lords publisher Hooded Horse requires its developers not to use gen AI.

Whatever the case may be, NetEase isn't ditching generative AI anytime soon, so if that's a dealbreaker for you, then it's safe to continue swearing off the company's games. Stay tuned for more.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Nintendo Direct February 2026 Partner Showcase Confirmed for Tomorrow
item.content:encoded:
The wait is over (well, sort of, at least). Nintendo has announced a new Nintendo Direct Partner Showcase for tomorrow, and it'll contain info about upcoming games for both of the company's currently active consoles.

As revealed on social media platform X, the Direct Partner Showcase for February 2026 will air at 6am Pacific/9am Eastern tomorrow, and it'll feature "roughly 30 minutes" of information about games for both the Switch 2 and the original Switch.

Of course, as usual, Nintendo stops short of announcing exactly what games we'll be seeing during the show, but hey; it's not like we're going to have to wait very long to find out, eh?

You can expect to see info on a host of upcoming third-party Switch 2 games during the show; I'd be surprised if we didn't hear from the likes of Resident Evil Requiem and Pragmata, as well as potential wildcards like Square Enix's The Adventures of Elliot: The Millennium Tales.

Given that it's set for a 2026 release, I'd also be shocked if we didn't hear something about FromSoftware's upcoming multiplayer game The Duskbloods, especially in light of the fact that it's a Switch 2 exclusive that we still don't know too much about.

One game you definitely won't be hearing from during tomorrow's showcase is, of course, Take-Two and Gearbox's Borderlands 4. The two studios confirmed in a quarterly earnings report that development on the Switch 2 version of the looter-shooter has been paused indefinitely.

These shows almost always contain surprises of one kind or another, too, so there will almost certainly be games that we don't know about yet. If Nintendo wants to drum up hype for the Switch 2, that's a great way to do so (although whether it needs to is another question!).

In any case, we'll learn exactly what Nintendo has in store for the new Direct when it airs tomorrow at 6am Pacific (that's 9am Eastern and 2pm GMT). We'll bring you all of the announcements from that show as soon as we get them.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Borderlands 4's Switch 2 Port May Never See the Light of Day
item.content:encoded:
Development work on the Switch 2 port of looter-shooter Borderlands 4 has been halted indefinitely, according to Take-Two, so if you're waiting to check the game out on Nintendo's new machine, you may want to look elsewhere instead.

The release of the game's Switch 2 version was indefinitely delayed back in September, but as far as we knew, developer Gearbox was still working on the port. Now, however, according to Variety, that's no longer the case.

Take-Two spokesman Alan Lewis told Variety that the company has made the "difficult decision" to pause development on Borderlands 4 for Switch 2, but that "post-launch content" and "ongoing improvements to optimize the game" on other platforms are still a priority.

Other Take-Two Switch 2 releases, like upcoming sports titles PGA Tour 2K25 and WWE 2K26, are unaffected, of course, but Borderlands 4 probably isn't going to be making an appearance on the console anytime soon.

Of course, given the game's well-documented performance woes on PC (whatever Gearbox head Randy Pitchford might say), it's not really a surprise that Take-Two doesn't seem to have been able to arrive at a satisfactory Switch 2 port for Borderlands 4.

This news was revealed alongside Take-Two's quarterly earnings report for the third quarter of the fiscal year, in which the company revealed its net bookings have grown by 28% compared to the same period last year.

Back then, CEO Strauss Zelnick was confident that upcoming juggernaut Grand Theft Auto 6 would arrive in a timely fashion in fall 2025, but as we now know, that proved to be a rather optimistic estimate for the game's release date.

Despite that, Take-Two reaffirms GTA 6's current release date of November 19th in its earnings release, as well as confirming that Grand Theft Auto 5 has now sold over 225 million copies across all platforms. Yes, you read that figure right.

You can check out Take-Two's full investor slideshow here for more information about its Q3 financial performance. Stay tuned for more.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph
